sp.p: But a good eſtate in aid of a commiſſion may do ſomething.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: A good eſtate, truly! where ſhou'd he get a good eſtate pray?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Why ſuppoſe now a worthy old gentleman on his death-bed ſhould have taken it in mind to leave him one—

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Hah! what's that you ſay?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: O ho! you begin to ſmell a plot, do you?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Suppoſe there ſhould be a paper in the world that runs thus—"I do hereby give and bequeath all my eſtates, real and perſonal, to Charles Dudley, ſon of my late daughter Louiſa, &c. &c. &c."

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Why I am thunder-ſtruck! by what contrivance, what villany did you get poſſeſſion of that paper?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: There was no villany, Madam, in getting poſſeſſion of it; the crime was in concealing it, none in bringing it to light.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Oh, that curſed lawyer, Varland!

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: You may ſay that, faith, he is a curſed lawyer, and a curſed piece of work I had to get the paper from him; your ladyſhip now was to have paid him five thouſand pounds for it, I forc'd him to give it me of his own accord for nothing at all, at all.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Is it you that have done this? Am I foil'd by your blundering contrivances, after all?

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: 'Twas a blunder, faith, but as natural a one as if I'd made it o' purpoſe.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Come, let us not oppreſs the fallen; do right even now, and you ſhall have no cauſe to complain.

sp.speaker: Lady RUSPORT.
sp.p: Am I become an object of your pity then? Inſufferable! confuſion light amongſt you! marry and be wretched: let me never ſee you more.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: She is outrageous; I ſuffer for her, and bluſh to ſee her thus expoſed.

sp.speaker: CHARLES.
sp.p: Come, Charlotte, don't let this angry woman diſturb our happineſs: we will ſave her in ſpite of herſelf; your father's memory ſhall not be ſtained by the diſcredit of his ſecond choice.

sp.speaker: CHARLOTTE.
sp.p: I truſt implicitly to your diſcretion, and am in all things yours.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Now, lovely but obdurate, does not this example ſoften?

sp.speaker: LOUISA.
sp.p: What can you aſk for more? Accept my hand, accept my willing heart.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: O bliſs inutterable! brother, father, friend, and you the author of this general joy—

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: Bleſſing of St. Patrick upon us all! 'tis a night of wonderful and ſurprizing ups and downs: I wiſh we were all fairly ſet down to ſupper, and there was an end on't.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: Hold for a moment! I have yet one word to interpoſe—Intitled by my friendſhip to a voice in your diſpoſal, I have approv'd your match; there yet remains a father's conſent to be obtain'd.

sp.speaker: BELCOOUR.
sp.p: Have I a father?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: You have a father: did not I tell you I had a diſcovery to make? Compoſe yourſelf: you have a father, who obſerves, who knows, who loves you.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: Keep me no longer in ſuſpence; my heart is ſoften'd for the affecting diſcovery, and nature fits me to receive his bleſſing.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: I am your father.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: My father? Do I live?

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p: I am your father.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: It is too much; my happineſs o'erpowers me; to gain a friend and find a father is too much; I bluſh to think how little I deſerve you.

sp.speaker: DUDLEY.
sp.p: See, children, how many new relations ſpring from this night's unforeſeen events, to endear us to each other.

sp.speaker: O'FLAHERTY.
sp.p: O my conſcience, I think we ſhall be all related by and bye.

sp.speaker: STOCKWELL.
sp.p:
How happily has this evening concluded, and yet how threatning was its approach! let us repair to the supper room, where I will unfold to you every circumſtance of my myſterious ſtory. Yes, Belcour, I have
watch'd you with a patient, but enquiring eye, and I have diſcover'd thro' the veil of ſome irregularities, a heart beaming with benevolence, an animated nature, fallible indeed, but not incorrigible; and your election of this excellent young lady makes me glory in acknowledging you to be my ſon.

sp.speaker: BELCOUR.
sp.p: I thank you, and in my turn glory in the father I have gained: ſenſibly impreſt with gratitude for ſuch extraordinary diſpenſations, I beſeech you, amiable Louiſa, for the time to come, whenever you perceive me deviating into error or offence, bring only to my mind the Providence of this night, and I will turn to reaſon and obey.

div.head: EPILOGUE. Written by D. G. ESQ. SPOKEN BY Mrs. ABINGTON.
div.stage: N. B. The Lines in Italics are to be ſpoken in a catechiſt T ••• .

lg.l: CONFESS, good folks, has not Miſs Ruſport ſhewn,
Strange whim • for SEVENTEEN HUNDRED SEVENTY-ONE?
What, pawn her jewels!—there's a precious plan!
To extricate from want a brave old man;
And fall in love with poverty and honour;
A girl of fortune, faſhion!—Fie upon her.
But do not think we females of the ſtage,
So dead to the refinements of the age,
That we agree with our old faſhion'd poet:
I am point blank againſt him, and I'll ſhew it:
And that my tongue may more politely run,
Make me a lady—Lady Blabington.
Now, with a rank and title to be free,
I'll make a catechiſm—and you ſhall ſee,
What is the veritable Braums de Vie:
As I change place, I ſtand for that, or this,
My Lady queſtions firſt—then anſwers Miſs.
"Come, tell me, Child, what were our modes and dreſs,
"In thoſe ſtrange times of that old fright Queen Beſ • !"—
And now for Miſs—

div.stage: She changes place, and ſpeaks for Miſs.

l.hi: Ladies were diſmal beings, ſeldom ſeen;
They roſe betimes, and breakfaſted as ſoon
On beef and beer, then ſtudied Greek till noon;
Unpainted cheeks with bl • ſh of health did glow,
Beruff'd and fardingal'd from top to toe,
Nor necks, nor ancles would they ever ſhew.

lg.l: Learnt Greek!— laughs.—Our outſide head takes half a day;
Have we much time to dreſs the inſide, pray?
No heads dreſs'd à la Greque; the ancients quote,
There may be learning in a papilloi • :
Cards are our claſſicks; and I, Lady B,
In learning will not yield to any ſhe,
Of the late founded female univerſity.
But now for Lady Blab—
"Tell me, Miſs Nancy,
"What ſports and what employments did they fancy?"

l.hi: The vulgar creatures ſeldom left their houſes,
But taught their children, work'd, and lov'd their ſpouſes;
The uſe of cards at Chriſtmas only knew,
They play'd for little, and their games were few,
One-and-thirty, P • t, All-f •• rs, and Laui • r • Loo;
They here a rate of mortals ſtout and boney,
And never heard the name of Macaroni.—

lg.l: "Oh brava, brava! that's my pretty dear—
"Now let a modern, modiſh fair appear;
"No more of theſe old dowdy maids and wives,
"Tell how ſuperior beings paſs their lives."—

l.hi: Till noon they ſleep, from noon till night they dreſs,
From night till noon they gaine it more or leſs,
Next night the ſame ſweet courſe of joy run o'er,
Then the night after as the night before,
And the night after that, encore, encore!—

lg.l: Thus with our cards we ſ • uff • e off all ſorrow,
To mor • ow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow:
We deal apace, from youth unto our prime,
And all our ye •• erdays, from rout and d •• m,
Have lighted • ools with empty pockets nome.
Thus do our lives with rapture roll away,
Not with the nonſenſe of our author's play;
Don't ſ • a • l and ſigh for good Q •• en • eſs's days:
For all you look ſo ſour, and bend the •• ow,
You all rejoice with me, you're living now,
